_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SUPHERB FARMS, INC. TURLOCK PLANT

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (CALARP) AND PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA REFRIGERATION SYSTEM CHLORINE WATER TREATMENT SYSTEM



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY: Revised August 2017 Rev.3



SupHerb Farms, Inc. (SupHerb Farms) prepared a Chemical Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) for its Turlock plant in general accordance with state and federal regulations. The state risk management regulations, also referred to as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP), are codified in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Section 2745, et. seq. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable substances. The federal regulations are codified in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 40, Section 68. Finally, both the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) and the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulate facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the PSM standards as defined in CCR, Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Part 1910, Section 119, respectively.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

SupHerb prepared the RMP/PSM Program to satisfy regulatory requirements and to demonstrate a commitment to evaluate and improve anhydrous ammonia and chlorine handling systems and practices at the facility. In the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the facility, SupHerb Farms has written an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) and personnel are trained in the appropriate response measures, relying on emergency services provided by the local fire department and the Stanislaus County Hazardous Materials Response team. SupHerb will continue to improve ammonia-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the RMP/PSM Program.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

SupHerb

Farms is located at 300 Dianne Drive, Turlock, California. The area is zoned for industrial use. This facility processes herbs and specialty vegetables by freezing and/or other processing. Fresh  herbs and specialty vegetables are processed through an Instant Quick Freeze (IQF) tunnel. Frozen herbs are packaged for wholesale markets or processed through a paste line. Cold storage is also provided within the warehouse for holding packaged final products. The NAICS Code for the facility is 311411 Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing.



Anhydrous ammonia (CAS No. 7664-41-7) is the regulated substance used in the facility's refrigeration system. The refrigeration system, which is a closed system, contains approximately 19,300 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The system provides cooling to the cold storage rooms, and processing lines. The cold rooms are used to store finished products ready for shipping.





Chlorine (CAS No. 7782-50-5) is utilized as a biocide to disinfect the process water in the facility which is used three wash lines. The source of chlorine for the chlorination system during normal operation is a one-ton container. Two one-ton containers may be on site, resulting in a maximum chlorine inventory of 4,000 pounds. At times 150 Lb. bottles are used when the ton cylinders are running low.

The RMP regulations require facilities to identify and evaluate chemical release scenarios resulting from potential failures of the chemical handling systems covered by the RMP. Program 3 requirements of the RMP apply to the SupHerb Farms facility due to the quantity of ammonia used. Program 3 facilities are required to evaluate a worst-case release scenario (release parameters are defined by the regulations) and an alternative release scenario. The regulations define a worst-case release scenario as "...the greatest amount held in a single vessel...released as a gas over 10 minutes." An alternative release scenario is identified as a release that is more lik

ely to occur at the facility. The EPA require it reaches one receptor.





This team has prepared worst-case and alternative release scenarios. These are not summarized herein as recommended by EPA, but are presented in the RMP.



General Accidental Release Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The CALARP/RMP/PSM regulations require a review of the accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps used by the facility. SupHerb Farms has incorporated many safety features in the ammonia refrigeration system and chlorine wash tank process to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. One safety concern with closed-loop ammonia system or a chlorine cylinder is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The second is a component failure. The SupHerb Farms ammonia and chlorine process has safeties and cutouts that shut down pump components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the ammonia and chlorine processes are equipped with pressure relief valves on pressure vessels and most chlorine cylinders. Additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped. The ammonia pressure relief valves discharge into a diffusion tank of adequate capacity. The chlorine cylinder would release to atmosphere.



The chlorine system is, for the most part, under less than atmospheric pressure with only the two one-ton cylinders and vacuum regulators operated at above atmospheric pressure. The vacuum regulators will shut off chlorine flow if vacuum is lost anywhere in the delivery piping.



Other safety features at the facility include:

?    Ammonia leak detection in the engine room

?    Chlorine release detection in the incoming vegetable wash line area

?    Remote emergency shutdown switch

?    Fire sprinklers indoors throughout the facility

?    Component-specific safety shutdowns

?    Personnel Monitors

?    Monitoring by pe

rsonnel



In addition to the physical features of the ammonia refrigeration and chlorine processes at the facility, SupHerb Farms has extensive administrative controls in place to maintain safe operation of the systems. Administrative controls include, but are not limited to, formal training programs for system operators and mechanics, emergency response training, a hot work permit program, a lock out/tag out program, a contractor safety program, incident investigation program, mechanical integrity program, management of change program, pre start-up safety review program, system entry/line break and an RMP/PSM auditing and inspection program. Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) are prepared for the ammonia and chlorine systems at the facility. 



The SOPs are a big part of the site specific operator training and a ready reference for operating and trouble-shooting the systems.





SupHerb Farms is committed to maintaining the mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration and chlorine systems. A preventive maintenance system is utilized to manage the maintenance of the refrigeration system. Preventive maintenance at the facility includes shift, daily, weekly, and periodic inspection; calibration; testing; and overhaul of ammonia system equipment. The system is used to track equipment performance and to create reports that are used by maintenance personnel to monitor the frequency of repairs and deviations from normal operating parameters.





Five-Year Accident History

The CALARP/RMP/PSM regulations require a review of the five-year accident history at the regulated facility. 

?    SupHerb Farms has had no reportable accidental releases of ammonia or chlorine during the past five years.





Emergency Response/Action Program

SupHerb Farms has a written Emergency Response (Action) Plan (EAP) that identifies emergency personnel responsibilities, procedures, evacuation measures and reporting requirements. The EAP is considered an action plan, not a resp

onse to mitigate the release. The EAP does not provide for release mitigation by facility employees. The facility relies on outside support for mitigation of an ammonia release. This support would be provided by the Turlock Fire Department and Stanislaus County Hazardous Materials Response Team. The most senior SupHerb Farms management team member onsite will assume the duty of Manager-in-Charge and make sure employees, contractors, and visitors have safely evacuated or are sheltering in place. The most senior Turlock Fire Department person present will assume the duty of Incident Commander upon arrival at the facility. The Incident Commander will have the responsibility of notifying other agencies concerning the incident. The Incident Commander will have the responsibility for any first aid rendered at the site. A copy of the EAP will be kept with the RMP documentation.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety Driven by this MOC and the 2017 PHA



SupHerb Farms has revalidated its Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for ammonia and chlorine in 2014 by including the 2014 scenerios in the 2017 New Chlorine PHA. A priority list of suggested mitigating recommendations was completed. SupHerb Farms will respond to suggested mitigation measures promptly and has established completion schedules for proposed actions. Management responses and support will be consistent with SupHerb Farms commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations. Current changes being evaluated include:

?    Recommend installing signage to light supports. Chlorine high level alarm

?    Add monthly bump testing for hand held monitors to your PM program.

?    Verify on-going PSM / RMP meetings are taking place at least quarterly and minutes are posted when changes are made to process or procedures.

?    Complete 3 yr. refresher training.

?    Install valve tags per the P&ID

?    Add emphasis on this during training: Add do not touch to operator training. Making it clear they notify maintenance if adjustments

are necessary.

?    Recommend installing wind direction indicators in area at face level.

?    PSIG to provide an active shooter template.

?    Verify you have a flood plan/severe weather in place.

?    Ensure office has developed Bomb Threat Procedure and/or checklist.







SupHerb Farms recognizes that the RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as SupHerb Farms continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. SupHerb Farms will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with SupHerb Farms internal review practices, and SupHerb Farms will maintain the most current versions on site. Thus, the most current version RMP/PSM and related documents and elements maintained on site may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies.
